abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the SCARP
            Transition Pilot Project for Pakistan. The outcome of the
            project was satisfactory. It fully achieved its ambitious
            institutional objectives. Responsibility for
            groundwater-based irrigation and vertical drainage was
            successfully transferred to the private sector without the
            angry demonstrations that had been anticipated. Despite
            having to absorb irrigation and drainage costs, farmers were
            able to increase their productivity enough to come out
            ahead. The sustainability of the project is likely. The main
            lesson from this pilot project is that Pakistan and the Bank
            lost an early opportunity to save significant operations and
            maintenance expenditures because they hung onto the public
            sector SCARP model for too long. From inception of the idea
            for a transition project in 1980, it took more than a decade
            to prove it would work. In preparing the follow-on projects,
            both the Bank and Borrower are mindful of the lessons of the
            SCARP Transition Pilot Project. The new project will focus
            its promotional efforts exclusively on community-owned wells
            rather than a large number of underutilized individually
            owned wells because community-owned wells will provide the
            greatest social benefits.
